ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I have developed a deeper understanding of how to accurately analyze (dense) anthropological and philosophical texts. And from that analysis discuss these complex ideas in a seminar format (with about 5 other active participants). It was truly enlightening.
I learned about theories of the self and agency. Learned how to parse somewhat-convoluted texts.
You will develop skills on reading academic books especially on psychology and just by practice will improve your reading and writing!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Discussions were sometimes a bit dry but mostly engaging. Sometimes the prof would go on long tangents that would sort of kill the discussion. Also it was a little awkward to find the right time to jump in (still am not sure whether we could just hop into the discussion or if we should have raised our hands). 

The format of the weekly homeworks (taking notes on the readings and submitting those notes) was nice!

This course is super engaging and interesting! Prof. Kockelman is extremely knowledgable on all these topics and reading and he really lets you explore the ideas! The only maybe weakness of the class, which I would argue is not a weakness but something that often happens in college, is that you don't receive grades throughout the semester so you can't really gauge how well you're doing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Because this class is simply reading, writing, and discussing it is fairly easy to translate into an online course!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! If you are interested in the topic and are wondering about relationships, the self, interactions, etc. I really recommend this course.

Yes! Take a look at the syllabus and see if you're interested in the course content because it definitely offers a good overview of agency, personhood, subjectivity, and selfhood. Though at times it definitely waxed a little more philosophical and it was sometimes hard to see the practical relevance of a topic. Also the vast majority of readings were by old white men and it really reflected in the content of the readings sometimes.
Yes I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone! As long as you don't hate writing enough to be scared away by the final paper, you should take the class!
